articles.headline: Solar Company Seeks Stiff U.S. Tariffs to Deter Chinese Spying
articles.snippet: An Oregon-based solar company is proposing that punitive tariffs be imposed on Chinese manufacturers that have benefited from online espionage.
articles.abstract: An Oregon-based solar company is proposing that punitive tariffs be imposed on Chinese manufacturers that have benefited from online espionage.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the daunting battle against corporate online espionage worldwide, one major solar company wants to deploy a powerful and novel weapon: higher tariffs.

articles.headline: NATO Weighs Rapid Response Force for Eastern Europe
articles.snippet: NATO leaders are expected to respond to increased Russian intervention in Ukraine by establishing a force capable of deploying quickly to Eastern Europe.
articles.abstract: NATO leaders are expected to respond to increased Russian intervention in Ukraine by establishing a force capable of deploying quickly to Eastern Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Ukrainian leaders warned on Monday of “a great war” with Russia, NATO leaders meeting in Wales this week were expected to endorse their most concrete response yet to increased Russian military intervention in Ukraine: establishing a rapid-reaction force capable of deploying quickly to Eastern Europe, officials of the alliance said.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Boot Camp for Bankers
articles.snippet: As they struggle to find new business to bolster sluggish earnings, banks consider the nation’s 25 million veterans and service members ideal customers.
articles.abstract: As they struggle to find new business to bolster sluggish earnings, banks consider the nation’s 25 million veterans and service members ideal customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert Vickers struggled not to grin, but the camouflage-clad drill sergeant caught him anyway.

articles.headline: Public Pension Funds Stay Mum on Corporate Expats
articles.snippet: Public pension funds have major stakes in American companies moving overseas to cut their tax bills. But they are saying little about the strategy, which could hurt the nation’s tax base.
articles.abstract: Public pension funds have major stakes in American companies moving overseas to cut their tax bills. But they are saying little about the strategy, which could hurt the nation’s tax base.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the outcry about the recent merger mania to take advantage of the tax avoidance transactions known as inversions, certain key players have been notably silent: public pension funds.

articles.headline: Infrastructure Cracks as Los Angeles Defers Repairs
articles.snippet: Los Angeles’s decaying roads, sidewalks and water system reflect the challenges many American cities face after years of belt-tightening prompted them to delay basic maintenance.
articles.abstract: Los Angeles’s decaying roads, sidewalks and water system reflect the challenges many American cities face after years of belt-tightening prompted them to delay basic maintenance.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The scene was apocalyptic: a torrent of water from a ruptured pipe valve bursting through Sunset Boulevard, hurling chunks of asphalt 40 feet into the air as it closed down the celebrated thoroughfare and inundated the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles. By the time emergency crews patched the pipe, 20 million gallons of water had cascaded across the college grounds.

articles.headline: Years of Rape and ‘Utter Contempt’ in Britain
articles.snippet: In Rotherham, England, at least 1,400 children were lured into a network of sexual exploitation while the authorities looked the other way.
articles.abstract: In Rotherham, England, at least 1,400 children were lured into a network of sexual exploitation while the authorities looked the other way.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROTHERHAM, England — It started on the bumper cars in the children’s arcade of the local shopping mall. Lucy was 12, and a group of teenage boys, handsome and flirtatious, treated her and her friends to free rides and ice cream after school.

articles.headline: Smaller Military Hospitals Said to Put Patients at Risk
articles.snippet: Many of the hospitals run by the armed forces are so small and the trickle of patients so thin that doctors and nurses say their ability to properly treat serious illnesses is compromised.
articles.abstract: Many of the hospitals run by the armed forces are so small and the trickle of patients so thin that doctors and nurses say their ability to properly treat serious illnesses is compromised.
articles.lead_paragraph: HINESVILLE, Ga. — Every year, more than 25,000 Americans undergo surgery to correct a hiatal hernia, a condition in which tissue from the stomach bulges into the chest cavity through a hole in the diaphragm. The hernias often return, but major complications are rare. Hospital stays are usually short.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: New York Accuses Evans Bank of Redlining
articles.snippet: Eric T. Schneiderman, New York’s attorney general, filed a suit on Tuesday that accuses Evans Bank of denying mortgages to African-Americans in Buffalo regardless of their credit.
articles.abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman, New York’s attorney general, filed a suit on Tuesday that accuses Evans Bank of denying mortgages to African-Americans in Buffalo regardless of their credit.

articles.headline: Publisher of The Washington Post Will Resign
articles.snippet: Katharine Weymouth, the publisher for almost seven years, will be replaced by Frederick J. Ryan Jr., a founder of Politico and a former Reagan administration official.
articles.abstract: Katharine Weymouth, the publisher for almost seven years, will be replaced by Frederick J. Ryan Jr., a founder of Politico and a former Reagan administration official.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Washington Post announced on Tuesday that its publisher, Katharine Weymouth, was stepping down, signaling the end of the Graham family’s connection to the newspaper it owned for 80 years before selling it last year to Jeffrey P. Bezos, the founder of Amazon.
